attribution: Library and University Collections, The University of Edinburgh

metadata.value: Charter of feu-farm by Alexander [Campbell], bishop of Brechin, with consent of the chapter, granting to Charles Dempster of Balronye and Helen Lindesay, his spouse, in conjunct fee, and their heir-male, the half of the lands of Balronye, Bellehill, the grain-mill of the same, the multures of Brathinch (or Brachinch) and the ‘ring beir’ used and wont. Confirming also a charter by the deceased John, bishop of Brechin, to the deceased Charles Dempster, father of the present Charles, of the other half of the said lands: To be held of the granter and his successors in feu-farm; paying the sum of £12 annually for each half of the lands, or £24 in all, which duplicated at entry of heirs and other services. Precept of sasine directed to John Oudny. Dated at St. Andrews, 9th December 1566, and signed by the bishop and various members of the chapter. Witnesses, Thomas Buchanan and Robert Incheocht, regents of St. Salvator’s College, John Oudny, citizen of Brechin, and Andrew Greiff, notary public. Two seals attached, in good condition, chapter and bishop’s.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: This charter was written by Alexander, the King of Scots about the gift of fifty acres of land from John de Monteforti to his brother, Alexander De Monteforti. The charter was witnessed by six men and holds the seal of Margaret, widow of Prince Alexander, son of King Alexander the 3rd whom this doucment was written under. The seal itself is in partial condition and depits a figure holding a sword. Information on the charters found from: Anderson, John, Rev, ed. Calendar of the Laing Charters, A.D. 854-1837 Belonging to the University of Edinburgh. Burlington: TannerRitchie, 2010. Print.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Charter of Eustace de Verci, addressed to all his men, Franks and Anglicis (‘Francis et Anglicis’) granting to WALTER of ANER, for his homage, those two oxgangs (bovates) pf land in Lium {Lyham} which Testard and Sunnira, his wife, held, to him and his heirs, to be held of the granter and his heirs as freely as he holds any other land in the same vill, performing the forinsec service as far as pertains to two oxgangs to his other holding in the same vill. Witnesses, Richard of Vesci, cleric, [a name partly defaced, according to a copy ‘German Tisun’ but doubtful], Eudo de Karl[iol], of Robert, Waldeve Forestar, Hugh of Morewie, Thomas Latimer, Thomas of Wetewud, and Robin Goher. Fragment of seal attached. Dated c. 1207. Cf. Liber de Kalchon.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Agreement made in the presence of Adam, Earl of Karrick, appointed in place of Sir Alexander Cumyn, Earl of Buchan, justiciar of Scotland, and a full court of Fiffe and of Fothref, in the moor of Pethcorthin, between Sir Richard Siuuarde, Lord of Kelli, on one part, and Sir Richard Chamberlain, lord of Gibbotistun, and Dame Johanna, his spouse, on the other part, whereby Siuuarde, for himself and his heirs, that they shall have common pasturage in the moor of Kellin for fifty animals, as many oxen as cows, and seven and twenty sheep, now shall they have more animals without permission of Siuuarde or his heirs, nor shall they claim any other right in that moor for any reason. He also grants them forty cartloads (‘carratas’) of peats in the great peatary of Kellin, and forty cartloads in the peatary which is between ‘Belighistoun’ and ‘Qaghinhacer’ which is called ‘Stinchandemure.’ He further quitclaims to them all right in the land which Buchach of Balmalkin ploughed on the north side of Kinkathislaw, and as that arable land extends towards the north to the marches of Casgengrey, with all the moor on the west side to the marches of Kinbrachmond; all to be held in property peaceably. And Chamberlian and his wiofe quitclaim to Siuuarde the pool or stank (‘stagnium’) called the pool of Kellin, with all the grazing (herbagio) of that pool, so that an inundation of the water of that pool shall not hurt the said Sir Richard arable land; it being understood that Chamberlain and his wife have free ish and entry for their annuals to the said pasture. The seal of the said Sir Richard and Dame Johanna [now wanting] being affixed to this portion of the agreement, and Sir R. Siuuarde’s to the other. Dated on Monday next after the feast of St. Michael, 3rd April 1266. Witnesses named, Sir Radulph of Lascelis, sheriff of Fife, Sir Richard of Bigirthon, Sir Richard of Maleuill, John of Kindeloch, John of Balkaschin, John Cook (‘coco’) of Abircrombin, Thomas Squire (‘scutifero’) the king’s judge, Hugh of Lochor, and William of Fordall.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Letter of procuratory to receive all assignment of the dowry due to Marguerite of Flanders. Letter has 2 wax seals attached.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Renaud, Count of Ghelre and lord of Lembourgh
metadata.label: Subject Person

metadata.value: Charter by Malcolm, [seventh] Earl of Fife, with consent of the Bishop and Chapter of Dunkeld, granting to the Church of the Holy Trinity at Scone the church of Rothgorthewen [Redgorton], with the lands, teinds, etc., of the same; to be holden as freely as any church in the kingdom of Scotland is held by an abbacy. Witnesses, J., abbot of Incheaffran, Sir H., prior of St. Colme, Sir William, archdeacon of Dunkeld, Dionisius, dean; Alan, parson of Munithin, chaplain of the earl; Richard parson of Stratmiggill, William of Wiwill, Elias od KInindmund, John of Methkil, Henry of Abbernith, William of Blare, Stephen of Melginche; William and Robert, clerks to the earl. No date, but about 25th May 1228, when it was confirmed by King Alexander the Second.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Charter by Malcolm, [seventh] Earl of Fife, with consent of the Bishop and Chapter of Dunkeld, granting to the Church of the Holy Trinity at Scone the church of Rothgorthewen [Redgorton], with the lands, teinds, etc., of the same; to be holden as freely as any church in the kingdom of Scotland is held by an abbacy. Witnesses, J., abbot of Incheaffran, Sir H., prior of St. Colme, Sir William, archdeacon of Dunkeld, Dionisius, dean; Alan, parson of Munithin, chaplain of the earl; Richard parson of Stratmiggill, William of Wiwill, Elias od KInindmund, John of Methkil, Henry of Abbernith, William of Blare, Stephen of Melginche; William and Robert, clerks to the earl. No date, but about 25th May 1228, when it was confirmed by King Alexander the Second.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Agreement made in the presence of Adam, Earl of Karrick, appointed in place of Sir Alexander Cumyn, Earl of Buchan, justiciar of Scotland, and a full court of Fiffe and of Fothref, in the moor of Pethcorthin, between Sir Richard Siuuarde, Lord of Kelli, on one part, and Sir Richard Chamberlain, lord of Gibbotistun, and Dame Johanna, his spouse, on the other part, whereby Siuuarde, for himself and his heirs, that they shall have common pasturage in the moor of Kellin for fifty animals, as many oxen as cows, and seven and twenty sheep, now shall they have more animals without permission of Siuuarde or his heirs, nor shall they claim any other right in that moor for any reason. He also grants them forty cartloads (‘carratas’) of peats in the great peatary of Kellin, and forty cartloads in the peatary which is between ‘Belighistoun’ and ‘Qaghinhacer’ which is called ‘Stinchandemure.’ He further quitclaims to them all right in the land which Buchach of Balmalkin ploughed on the north side of Kinkathislaw, and as that arable land extends towards the north to the marches of Casgengrey, with all the moor on the west side to the marches of Kinbrachmond; all to be held in property peaceably. And Chamberlian and his wiofe quitclaim to Siuuarde the pool or stank (‘stagnium’) called the pool of Kellin, with all the grazing (herbagio) of that pool, so that an inundation of the water of that pool shall not hurt the said Sir Richard arable land; it being understood that Chamberlain and his wife have free ish and entry for their annuals to the said pasture. The seal of the said Sir Richard and Dame Johanna [now wanting] being affixed to this portion of the agreement, and Sir R. Siuuarde’s to the other. Dated on Monday next after the feast of St. Michael, 3rd April 1266. Witnesses named, Sir Radulph of Lascelis, sheriff of Fife, Sir Richard of Bigirthon, Sir Richard of Maleuill, John of Kindeloch, John of Balkaschin, John Cook (‘coco’) of Abircrombin, Thomas Squire (‘scutifero’) the king’s judge, Hugh of Lochor, and William of Fordall.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Charter by Nicholas Corbet, granting and confirming to Simon of Holtehall and his wife, for their lifetime, all the conditions named in the charter granted by Sir William, son of Earl Patrick, father of the granter, to the Simon and his wife of the hospital in Newton in Glandalle, with a half carucate of land (measure of land based on being ploughed by oxen and men in a season) belonging to the hospital. The charter is witnessed by several men and has a seal (which is partially broken) of a knight riding to sinister with a shield. Information on charters found from: Anderson, John, Rev, ed. Calendar of the Laing Charters, A.D. 854-1837 Belonging to the University of Edinburgh. Burlington: TannerRitchie, 2010. Print.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Charter by Patrick Corbert, brother and heir of Sir Nicholas Corbert, granting to Thomas Baker (‘Pistori’) of Langetoun, in Glendale, a half carucate of lands, in tofts and meadows as well as arable lands, belonging to the Hospital of Great Neutoun in Glendale, for the purpose of sustaining three poor men of Christ in that hospital in reasonable food and clothing at the sight of faithful men, and if the three poor men will not labour, or do the best of their power or degree of infirmity what is commanded them, they shall at the will of the granter be expelled from the hospital and other three poor men substituted: To be holden freely to the grantee; reserving to the granter and his heirs the wood of Ruttok, which Thomas and his heirs are not to cut or use without leave; the said Thomas and his heirs being ‘rumfre’ and quit of multure for the grain of said hospital at the mill of Langetoun. With clause of warrandice. Witnesses, Sir William Heron, Sir Michael of Kylnum, David of Coupeland, knights, Maurice of Ewrth, Hugh of Heddon, Thomas of Paluxston, Nicholas son of Stephen of Couepland. No date, c. 1270-1280. Seal attached. A tree in the centre, with two animals, probably lions, rampant on the dexter and sinister sides of the stem, facing towards it, with two birds (ravens ?) on the upper branches of the tree. Legend somewhat defaced. This seal, which is small and shows no shield, appears ingeniously to show the arms of both the father and the mother of the granter- the lion of Dunbar and the raven or crow of Corbet.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Margaret, daughter of G. (Guy), Count of Flanders, wife of the late Alexander [The Third}, King of Scots
metadata.label: Creator

metadata.value: Letters of Margaret confirming prior letters of her father, Guy, to Sir Thibault of Mauritania to sell and alienate the dowry for Margaret's marrraige. The charter is dated at Bruges on September 18, 1285, the 4th day after the Exaltation of the Cross, and written in Norman-French. Included is a seal in good condition depicting possibily as Roman solider. 'Sigillum secretum' Information on charters from: Anderson, John, Rev, ed. Calendar of the Laing Charters, A.D. 854-1837 Belonging to the University of Edinburgh. Burlington: TannerRitchie, 2010. Print.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: The verso of this charter shows script by three different hands, two in original ink on the doucment itself and a later label with the number 12 written on it in modern red pen. The seal from the recto is repeated on the verso side as well and is partially missing in a very simialr way to the recto.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Charter of Eustace de Verci, addressed to all his men, Franks and Anglicis (‘Francis et Anglicis’) granting to WALTER of ANER, for his homage, those two oxgangs (bovates) pf land in Lium {Lyham} which Testard and Sunnira, his wife, held, to him and his heirs, to be held of the granter and his heirs as freely as he holds any other land in the same vill, performing the forinsec service as far as pertains to two oxgangs to his other holding in the same vill. Witnesses, Richard of Vesci, cleric, [a name partly defaced, according to a copy ‘German Tisun’ but doubtful], Eudo de Karl[iol], of Robert, Waldeve Forestar, Hugh of Morewie, Thomas Latimer, Thomas of Wetewud, and Robin Goher. Fragment of seal attached. Dated c. 1207. Cf. Liber de Kalchon.

canvases.label: Lands of Eastcraig, 15th July 1572, No.1524 recto
Lands of Stevinstoun, 12th Dec 1531, No.2275 recto

metadata.value: [12th December 1531] Instrument of Sasine following on a precept (dated Edinburgh, 14th November 1531) and directed to James Anderson in Prestoun, and Richard Diksone, as bailies, by John Inglis, the king’s marshall, lord of a third part of the lands of Stevinstoun, for infefting Patrick Hepburn of Wauchton, and Helena Hepburn, his spouse, in conjunct fee, and their heirs, in the granter’s third of the lands and barony of Stevinstoun, with the third part of the mill thereof, commonly called the “Shaddo Cauil,” in the constabulary of Haddington and sheriffdom of Edinburgh. Sasine given, 12th December 1531, by the said James Anderson. Witnesses, John Hepburn, John Quhitlaw, Richard Diksone, Alexander Tunno, and John Levintoune. Thomas Quhit, presbyter of St. Andrews diocese, by apostolic authority notary.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Page 2 of 2. One of over 3,000 charters held in the Laing collection. This charter is described in the Calendar of the Laing Charters as being a "Charter by Sir William Richardson, vicar perpetual of the parish church of St. Cuthbert of Langtoun, with consent of James [Stewart], commendator of Kelso, and John [Philp], abbot of Lindores, administrator of Kelso, granting to WILLIAM COCKBURN of Chowslie and MARGARET GALBRAITH, his spouse, the lands of Gretrig, Vicar's Croft, Hauchis, Langlands and commonflat of said vicarage, in the barony of Langton, Berwickshire, except one croft on the east side of the church called Hoy's Croft, now occupied by Kentigern Home, curate of the church, with pasture for one horse in the said lands: To be held in feu-farm for a yearly feu-duty (old and new) of nine merks 13s. 9d. Dated at Kelso, 30th October 1539. Witnesses, Mr. Patrick Cokburne, rector of Petcokkis, Alexander Gledstanis, rector of Garwod, Richard Richardson, vicar of Sproustoun, Richard Ker, James Lawson of Hundby, Thomas Makdowale of Makcarstoun, Alexander Hoppringill, Sir William Chepman, and Sir Thomas Quhite, chaplains, Sirs Robert Lausoun, Thomas Watho, and John Rolland, notaries. Signed by the commendator, abbot, and the following members of the convent: William Newtone, William Lausoun, Walter Murray, Adam Chatto, Robert Lawsoun, John Paton, James Ancrum, George Gray, Jasper Wynrem, William Wrangham, Thomas Turnet, John Cosar, Thomas Newmouch, Michael Chatto, Thomas Schaw, Alexander Wod, Thomas Symson, and Patrick Ogyll. Thomas Watho, notary, signs for William Richardson. Seal of Richardson (a chevron) and that of the commendator of Kelso still attached". The Kelso seal is attached near the middle of the document and shows the Virgin and child. The seal of Sir William Richardson is attached to the left. A third seal is missing.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: J. Anderson, Calendar of the Laing Charters, A.D. 854-1837, belonging to the University of Edinburgh (1899).
metadata.label: Reference

metadata.value: Detail of the witnesses signatures to the charter including Patrick Smyth of Baco, Andrew Smyth, David Heart of Rusland, William and Mr. John Heart and Mr. James Heyne, minister at Kirkwall.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: This charter is written as a formal document following the marraige of Mr. Patrick Grahame and Anna Stewart in term of the land and rent in which they two will now share. The document goes into great detail of which land is now in the ownership of the two after the marraige and the yearly rentals made from the 'meills'. There is no seal on this charter but on the bottom right, the signatures of the participants and witnesses can be found. Information on the charter found: Anderson, John, Rev, ed. Calendar of the Laing Charters, A.D. 854-1837 Belonging to the University of Edinburgh. Burlington: TannerRitchie, 2010. Print.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Aggregate photograph of several charters from the Laing Collection. The charters are depicted in their folded state and many of the library shelfmarks and charter numbers are visible.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: The shelves housing the Charters in the Laing Collection in the Treasures Room, on the 5th floor of the Centre for Research Collections, 2012.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Charter by King James V to the tenants of the crown lands of Ferifelde and Bonfelde, in Fife, 28th March 1522, No.63 verso

metadata.value: Charter by King James V to the tenants of the crown lands of Ferifelde and Bonfelde, in Fife, 28th March 1522
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: 1 of 2. Charter (written in Latin) under the Great Seal [not in printed register] by King James V, with consent of John, Duke of Albany, Governor, to the tenants now occupiers and possessors of the crown lands of Ferifelde and Bonfelde, in the lordship and shire of Fife, granting to them these whole lands, namely to each of said tenants the portion of the lands which they or their ancestors had occupied: To be held in feu-farm, etc., and burgage of the burgh of Cupar in Fife, for payment of £20 Scots annually proportionally to each tenant. Dated at Edinburgh, 28th March 1522. Witnesses, James [Betoun], archbishop of Glasgow, chancellor, David [Arnot], bishop of Galloway, etc., David [Hamilton], bishop of Lismore, Alexander, Earl of Huntly, James, Earl of Arran, Hugh, Earl of Eglinton, John, prior of St. Andrews, vicar-general (the see being vacant), George, abbot of Holyrood, Privy Seal, and Robert, abbot of Paisley.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Charter by King James V to the tenants of the crown lands of Ferifelde and Bonfelde, in Fife, 28th March 1522, No.63 verso

Dated at Edinburgh, 28th March 1522. Tyl al men yis present write to her or see vs John lorde of Hahburtone, No.805

metadata.value: Tyl al men yis present write to her or see vs John lorde of Hahburtone
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: [10th May 1447.] Letter of Tack or Lease by John, Lord of Haliburtoun [in the vernacular], granting to his ‘well belufit squearies and men,’ Thomas and Alexander Haytly, brother-german, in lease for their lifetimes, that quarter of land of Lambdene which john Hatly formerly held of the granter’s late father, Sir Williams of Haliburtoin, the said Thomas and Alexander paying £5 Scots yearly, the granter’s ‘ladi moder’ receiving 33s. 4d. yearly as her terce. Dated at Drltoun, 10th May 1447. Winesses, John of Congilton of the Ilk, Richard of Congilton, Edward of Congilton, William of Lermonth, Richard the Vaus, and John Nicolson. Granter’s seal attached. Legend broken, but arms distinct: quarterly, first and fourth, a bend charged with three lozenges; second, three bars; and third, a bend. Crest defaced.
metadata.label: Description
